author: ThiefSakon

text:
This game was totally worth the important - and truly shimomura is a goddess in music design. 

I, for one, enjoyed the branching plots! Even the bad ends! The battle system was good too, I enjoyed decimating an enemy my making a huge combo with my team of aht, Raynie and stock, oft swapping Raynie with the big beast like guy! Even if it was only just for bonus exp.

author: william josed

text: Radiant Historia was recommended to me by the venerable HCBailly and to this day it remains one of my favorite JRPGs of all time. It has an incredible soundtrack, compelling characters, and one of the greatest story lines of a JRPG in recent memory. If you have not played this game, you owe to yourself to complete this gem.
author: TheSpiralArchitect

text:
+HoppytheCourier I remember that Let's Play. HCBailly even wrote a walkthrough on GameFAQs (his GameFAQs account being Sleipnir2000).
I remember how after HCBailly's Let's Play ended, they made more copies of Radiant Historia. If it was only a coincidence, it's still an awesome coincidence.
author: myohel0

text: It missed out on a decent print by under-printing which shot itself in the foot as far as sales.  It would have done alright if they had printed enough to meet demand.
author: ParrotMan01

text: I'm so glad I finally got to play this gem last summer. It's as good as Suikoden TIerkreis (maybe better).

text: Those cellos (?) are heavenly.
author: PsychadelicoDuck

text: It's so sad to hear this game didn't do so well, because in my opinion, I thought it was a fantastic RPG. Absolutely worth the time of anyone who enjoys a good dose of turn-based combat.
author: Medal Melodies

text: It feels like jrpg many times becomes hidden gems. Would you recommend it? If so, how does it stand above other jrpgs? What makes it unique?
author: Eirian Odalis

text: Eirian Odalis Brave Fencer Musashi for ps1 is a hidden gem too.
author: EJHC

text: I bought this game day one.  I think it's the best RPG on the DS by a mile.
author: Mimorin

text:
+Mimorin 
What about RPG's which grow you as the player from the story instead of watching everybody else grow and making "difficult" decisions for THEM?

I still think twewy is a more deserving title for best DS rpg for many reasons, especially the story, which had a big impact on me in my younger years as I am sure it did for many other people who played it.
author: bulbinking

text:
+bulbinking It's a matter of preference.  Radiant Historia is traditional and turn-based with a plot driven story while twewy is experimental and action-heavy with a character driven story.  Both did what they sought out to do well.  

At the time I craved something similar to Chrono Trigger and this was the closest they've gotten.  Unfortunately, the characters weren't nearly as memorable or developed.
author: Mimorin
bulbinking

text: You can change party,with a maximum of 3 members,but the ones that don't fight still receive a tiny amount of experience;it's not enough though and they fall behind pretty fast if you don't use them

text: bulbinking I understand the FE problem. You could always play Awakening, Birthright, Revelations, or Echoes though.

text: Such a good game.
author: Ben McManus

text: While I thought the splitting timelines mechanic ended up feeling like a chore to manage, I did really enjoy Radiant Historia. You just don't see new RPG IPs that often anymore, especially on a handheld. It's unfortunate that it didn't sell well and it's another sad example of why developers prefer pumping out sequels for established franchises.
